plist.p: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. We will now begin Banco do Brasil's First Quarter 2012 Results Conference Call. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later, we will conduct a question-and-answer session and instructions will be given at that time. As a reminder, this conference is being recorded and a live broadcast with the slide presentation on the Banco's Investor Relations website, where questions may be sent through.

Before proceeding, let me mention that this presentation may include references and statements, planned synergies, increasing estimates, projections of results and future strategy for Banco do Brasil, its associated and affiliated companies and subsidiaries. These expectations are highly dependent on market conditions, on Brazil's economic and banking system performances, as well as an international market one. Banco do Brasil is not responsible for bringing up to date any estimates in this presentation.

First, we are going to have some details of the results. At the end of the presentation, the executives will answer the questions from the participants. With us today are Mr. Ivan de Souza Monteiro, CFO; and Mr. Gustavo Sousa, Head of IR.
Mr. Gustavo, you may begin now.

Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in our first quarter 2012 earnings presentation. You will note (01:31) presentation that we made some changes in the format. We made it a little shorter and more objective and want to provide more time for the Q&A session.

Starting on slide three, we have the highlights of our earnings. We reached R$1 trillion in total assets, a growth of 16% year-on-year. Our total portfolio in a broad concept that includes privately issued securities – guarantees and retail portfolios that were brought after the association of the central bank Resolution 3533. The investment (02:09) reach R$473 billion, a 19% increase year-on-year. Our NII is growing within the guidance at 11.8%. Our delinquency rates are still the lowest in the banking industry and we saw a significant increase in fee, 23% year-on-year.

Moving to slide four, we have the breakdown of our operating revenue in our various operating expenses. Our NII again growing at 11.8%, which is the most important item in Banco do Brasil's operating revenues, which comes to 60% of our operating revenues. The fee income, that's R$5 billion, grew 23%.

And I'll also highlight the Previ item. This item is growing with our – with the accrual component only. And this accrual component for this first semester is that R$130 million per month. And in our operating expenses, we see a growth in admin expenses running at 16.4%. We will break down this item over the next slide.

And we also have (03:26) growth and our recurring net income at R$2.7 billion. The extraordinary items related to those are the economic trends, with a gross effect of R$361 million, for a net effect after-taxes and the participation in profits (3:49) of R$201 million. The tax rate is at 26% and this is just a near effect of a higher tax shield arrived in some pieces (4:02) and on capital.

On page five, we have the breakdown of sources and uses. That most important source item is still the deposits, which would stand for nearly three quarters of our total sources; this item grew 17.2% year-on-year.
I also highlighted the growth in commercial papers composed mostly by LCA, (04:28) that is a credit, and LF, the improvement of bank loan. This item is growing (04:35) and a specification (04:40).
In terms of our uses, I highlight the growth in our loan portfolio (04:46) the 2682 resolution of the central bank resulting, at this point, to 70.8% of Banco do Brasil's total investments.

Moving to slide six, we highlight a record amount in our foreign borrowing; we reached US$37.3 billion and we think that fairly (05:11) year-on-year and we highlight the bond issues above. Specifically, in January and February, we issued US$9.7 billion (05:22) that counts as Tier 1 capital. The issues in January with a recap in February added close to R$52 billion in our Tier 1 capital.

Moving to slide seven, we have a breakdown of our NII, and that highlights the gross and the revenue from loan operation, which expanded 16.9% year-on-year and our average share this February in our treasury results. It functions as Banco do Brasil's charges, (05:57) bank's liquidity and also to manage the bank's exposure to federal market (06:02).

On the move by segment, I highlight stability instead from one operation. Moving to slide eight, we have a breakdown of our loan portfolio. This portfolio grew 19% over the last 12 months, reaching R$473 billion, with a growth of 18% in the agribusiness portfolio, 14.2% on individuals portfolio and 17.8% under corporates portfolio.

Moving to slide nine, we have a breakdown of our portfolio, the credit portfolio with individuals, where we highlight the importance of the credit line that represents lower risk, such as payroll, foreign loan, auto finance and mortgages. These items correspond to 80% of Banco do Brasil's credit portfolio with individuals. And specifically payroll credit, which stands for nearly 40% of Banco do Brasil's individuals portfolio.

Moving to slide 10, we have the breakdown of our credit portfolio by (7:14) company in Brazil, where we showed an increase of 17.8% and I'll highlight the – our most important credit line for this segment, which is the working capital, which accounts for 53.8% of the total portfolio of our company.

Moving to slide 11, we have the breakdown of the portfolio with SMEs and with large corporations. The portfolio with SMEs grew by 24.3%, relying on the usage of the FGO, the Guaranteed Fund, the usage of the FGO through SME grew by 38.8% over the past 12 months.

Moving to slide 12, in our Agribusiness portfolio (08:02) where Banco do Brasil is the absolute leader. We're 63.7% market share. We saw an increase of 18.4% in the portfolio and this is broken down into the following components. We saw a 15.9% growth in credit for small producers, 25.7% in credit for mid-sized and large producers and a 20% growth in credit for company. The Agribusiness credits for company midsize is around 67.3% of our fellow Agribusiness portfolio. It gets further where we had very large EBITDA today which is 0.6% 90 days that's in delinquency.
Moving to slide 13, we have a comparison of Banco do Brasil's credit portfolio by risk model that the concentration in the AA to C of Banco do Brasil is superior to the average in the industry.

On slide 14, we have a breakdown of our NPL plus 90 days, when you compare Banco do Brasil's consolidated numbers in the blue line, we see an extend chain, but it's much better than the industry. And when you compare that with Banco do Brasil extreme operations in Banco Votorantim we see an improving trend.

Moving to slide 15 where we had a coverage ratio. The coverage ratio of Banco do Brasil's consolidated is on the yellow line and you can see that 210% (09:53) average of our peers. And Banco do Brasil excluding the operation trend Banco Votorantim showed an increase in the coverage ratio finishing March 2012 at 245%.

On slide 16, we project our quarterly credit provision expenses for the second quarter, third quarter, and fourth quarter, we know that analysts and investors that's following this very closely and we decided to give an objective number further as well as coming quarters as you can see on this slide.

Moving to slide 17, we have a breakdown of our administrative expenses. We have (10:37) expenses. The salary increase has happened at the end of the second semester, so the comparison of the first quarter of 2012 with the first quarter of 2011 is unfair on that specific point. We have a decent quarter-on-quarter due to a vacation effect that we have in Brazil that the analysts and investors are very familiar with.

On the other administrative expenses, we showed a growth of 15.9% or an overall growth of administrative expenses at 16.4%. The reason we have grown above our guidance in admin expenses is because of (11:25). We started consolidating the operations from (11:31) on the second half, so the comparison with the first quarter is not (11:36). And we also have new expenses (11:42) and other outsourced services that were not contained in the first quarter of 2011. When you view the market over the last 12 months, we see that we were within the guidance. So based on that we projected for the fiscal year of 2012, we will be within the guidance for average (12:06) expenses.

Moving to slide 18, we have the breakdown of our fee income which grew 23% year-on-year. It is based on the growth of the most important item. If we look at the first four items in this slide, account fees, fees from debit and credit cards, fees from asset management and fees related to credit operations, most of the items grew above 20% or close to 20% and this the reflection of the Banco do Brasil's investment in new platform that we call BB2.4 (12:44) where we added 10,000 employees to the branch network and we (12:51) IT so that we can provide a better level of service to our clients and extract more revenues out of the relationships.

On slide 19, we have our cost to income ratio. And this quarter we finished at 45.2% and recently we have an increase there. It's mainly because of a lower participation of Previ as we've discussed in the initial slides and the initial expenses of Banco Postal. Banco Postal directly contribute their improving revenues for Banco do Brasil but in the first quarter naturally the impact of the expenses is raised a little more.

Moving to slide 20, we have our BIS ratio of 14.3% as we've discussed. We had an increase of close to 52 basis points that come from the issuance of (13:48) in January and February, and a Tier 1 capital of 10.9%.

Slide 21 show a continuation of the (13:59) performance in the first quarter with the guidance (14:06). We are within the guidance for ROE, NII, and total deposits. We are growing slower (14:16) domestic loan portfolios, we are growing at 14.2% in individuals and 17% (14:21) company whereas these are achievable within the guidance for 2012 as a whole especially with the new program that you are very aware (14:40). In Agribusiness, we have given a better guidance mainly given the growth in credits to mid-size and large-size deal producers and the company's EBITDA on the previous slide.

The allowance for loan losses are within the guidance, fee income growing above the guidance, admin expenses above the guidance but we will be within the guidance for 2012. That's our projection and (14:58) given the factor I explained on the first slide. Thank you very much and let's now open the Q&A session.
